channel.title: Brandon Boswell
channel.description: Recent content from Brandon Boswell's Digital Garden

item.title: Paywalling your content actually limits your viral potential
item.description: The thought here is your persona in a given space is way more valuable than the money you will make off selling a course or paywalling your content, and instead should open it up to as many people as possible.
item.content:encoded:
The thought here is your persona in a given space is way more valuable than the money you will make off selling a course or paywalling your content, and instead should open it up to as many people as possible.

In thinking about this, I think it may be dependent on how niche your audience is. If you have truly unique and differentiated content and your audience is niche, then you may be better off paywalling it.

I think the counter-argument here is you still need a monetization strategy of some kind.

item.title: You can grow on Twitter by chipping away at it
item.description: Twitter I think YouTube is similar. If you’re making content of a minimum quality, then your channel will grow over time.
item.content:encoded:
Twitter

I think YouTube is similar. If you’re making content of a minimum quality, then your channel will grow over time.

item.title: Success on Twitter is about retweets
Boxes for each project
item.description: The box gave Twyla Tharp a way to put projects on hold and revisit them later: “The box makes me feel connected to a project… I feel this even when I’ve back-burnered a project: I may have put the box away on a shelf, but I know it’s there.
item.content:encoded:
The box gave Twyla Tharp a way to put projects on hold and revisit them later: “The box makes me feel connected to a project… I feel this even when I’ve back-burnered a project: I may have put the box away on a shelf, but I know it’s there. The project name on the box in bold black lettering is a constant reminder that I had an idea once and may come back to it very soon.” ( Location 1079)

Arc browser enables you to have collections for each of your digital projects. Easels within this allow you to do this digitally as well.

item.title: Customer Success
item.description: Front.com seems like a cool option for keeping your customer success operation personal without having to give out your personal email.
item.content:encoded: Front.com seems like a cool option for keeping your customer success operation personal without having to give out your personal email.

item.title: Don’t be afraid to promote your work more than once
item.description: The current lifespan of content on social media is so short these days that most people didn’t see it the first time. You are doing yourself a disservice by only posting it once.
item.content:encoded:
The current lifespan of content on social media is so short these days that most people didn’t see it the first time. You are doing yourself a disservice by only posting it once. Most of your audience is unlikely to see it.

Meta

Social Media Self Promotion

item.title: Consuming the news in the morning is inviting anxiety into your life
Ruby
item.description: Things I wish I knew earlier about Ruby Object is the root namespace You can call whereami from within a binding.pry statement to get back to the location you were originally at when the debugger kicked in.
item.content:encoded:
Things I wish I knew earlier about Ruby

  • Object is the root namespace
  • You can call whereami from within a binding.pry statement to get back to the location you were originally at when the debugger kicked in.

item.title: YouTube
item.description: You should have no fear of failure with YouTube because you can create as many videos as you want. There is no scarcity aside from your time to dedicate to your channel.
item.content:encoded:
You should have no fear of failure with YouTube because you can create as many videos as you want. There is no scarcity aside from your time to dedicate to your channel.

Contents

  • YouTube Shorts
  • YouTube Funnel
  • YouTube Algorithm
  • YouTube Script Writing
  • My YouTube Video Process
  • My Youtube Channel
  • Learnings from YouTube Videos

Ideas

  • Teaching on the internet is a hedged bet

item.title: Render Conference
item.description: https://player.vimeo.com/video/739652984 hosted by Betaworks Notes / Follow ups Howard Rheingold mentioned Social Capitol, Knowledge Capitol, Communion as the reasons for why people answer stranger’s questions on the internet. Also mentioned a book The extended mind for how physical interaction is important for learning and is a potential untapped area for digital tools.
item.content:encoded:
https://player.vimeo.com/video/739652984 hosted by Betaworks

Notes / Follow ups

Howard Rheingold mentioned Social Capitol, Knowledge Capitol, Communion as the reasons for why people answer stranger’s questions on the internet. Also mentioned a book The extended mind for how physical interaction is important for learning and is a potential untapped area for digital tools. eInk Digital Tablets may be a minor bridge of that.

“If you can automate a lower level process, then that frees up space for a higher level one.” This is how I think about productivity and what I try to enable with it.

item.title: Immersion Reading
item.description: Reading a book and listening to the audiobook at the same time in hopes of higher comprehension. I first heard this term from Daniel Doyon at Render Conference, but realized I had already tried this with How to Avoid a Climate Disaster on iPad.
item.content:encoded:
Reading a book and listening to the audiobook at the same time in hopes of higher comprehension. I first heard this term from Daniel Doyon at Render Conference, but realized I had already tried this with How to Avoid a Climate Disaster on iPad. I remember thinking it was cool, but the cost of having to buy the book and the audiobook was a turnoff that has prevented me from doing this further.

You can listen to this blurb at ~55:38 in the Render Conference Livestream

item.title: People Notes
item.description: PKM 2022-08-30 Time Soup asked on the My Youtube Channel: Bit of a random question but regarding the ‘people’ folder what sort of information do you put into files for your contacts (i.
item.content:encoded:
PKM

2022-08-30 Time Soup asked on the My Youtube Channel:

Bit of a random question but regarding the ‘people’ folder what sort of information do you put into files for your contacts (i.e. the people you know, not authors)?

Thanks for reaching out! There isn’t a ton of structure to the people notes aside from some automation to create an alias to the person’s first name, which is handy when referencing a person in my daily notes. In my case, I keep the notes for people I know and authors I read in the same folder. They are real people, after all, and some of the people whose content I consume I also end up connecting with virtually. Many of the notes are empty, but some have important information about the person that I don’t want to forget. Most importantly, they are landing places where I can look at the local graph to see all the interactions or times I have mentioned those people in my Daily Notes or Weekly Reflection. You also now have a person note in my PKM where I logged that we chatted in this comment thread today. Here’s to hoping we chat again in the future!

item.title: What tools for thinking are you most excited about?
item.description: I care deeply about Local First Software that reduces all possible friction from the human thought process. The intersection of Analog and Digital Tools (and helping people choose the right tool for their current step in the creative process) is also a personal interest.
item.content:encoded: I care deeply about Local First Software that reduces all possible friction from the human thought process. The intersection of Analog and Digital Tools (and helping people choose the right tool for their current step in the creative process) is also a personal interest. Finally, hybrid tools that bring digital convenience to historically analog tools are especially interesting to me.

item.title: ACCESS method
item.description: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p0zWJ-TLghw My initial impression was that the video serves a great foundation and example to prove to people that links and folders can coexist in a PKM system. I found that I landed on a very similar system between in my use of Obsidian and Arc.
item.content:encoded:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=p0zWJ-TLghw

My initial impression was that the video serves a great foundation and example to prove to people that links and folders can coexist in a PKM system.

I found that I landed on a very similar system between in my use of Obsidian and Arc. I found personally that PARA was not a great fit for Obsidian (You can watch that video here).

I don’t currently have multiple spaces in my Obsidian vault because I try to keep work things out of it (and in the work Notion), but I could see that being a good fit for people who do want/need to maintain work notes in their vault.

Overall, I would say check out the ACCESS method and grab the parts of it that make sense and work for you.
